I love it when characters are rude, distant, or mistrustful of me from the start because it adds so much backstory to their personalities and feels much more realistic.

Pros:
- Visually, it is stunning. The art design and decor for all the locations, characters etc. is really well done, everything looks so adorable.
- Game mechanics are good and they work. Getting around is easy, there is lots to do.
- Dialogues seem polished already. The characters have a personality that makes you want to remember them, which is something a lot of games struggle with these days with their generic ChatGPT bs.
- There is loads of customization, both for yourself, clothes (you can save and rapidly swap 5 outfits) as well as your plot (can use house templates, make your own from parts or use someone else's layout by searching for it).
- Coop isn't in the demo, but the final game will have one.

Cons:
- Loading times for the initial game and transition to the mine map and back take really long, but that's expected for a demo. Pretty sure this will get optimized. The game is stable so that's not an issue.
- They use a gear wheel to hold your tools, which is fine and all, but it seems to be the ONLY way to put stuff in your hand. This means that you have to constantly go through inventory -> map to gear wheel for every single use item you want to use in the game, then put your gear wheel back how you wanted it. There needs to be a way to equip something in your hand directly from the inventory without having to go through the gear wheel. The gear wheel should also have numbered shortcuts so you can use it like a hotbar.

Overall, this is what a demo / early access game should look like, not the bug infested and content devoid cashgrab a lot of games pull these days.

It's actually... pretty nice! They're mostly fetch quests that are fortunately not super grindy. Kinda wish the currency for upgrading skills isn't used for anything else though.

I approached this game with cautious optimism, but the demo has confirmed several of my initial concerns. My biggest worry was that the gameplay might not offer much novelty and would instead lean heavily on the familiar, overused cozy farming-sim formula‚Äîand unfortunately, the demo largely reinforces that impression.

For instance, the farming and animal-raising systems feel underdeveloped. You simply grow crops or raise animals and then sell everything directly to NPC vendors‚Äîany vendor, in fact. Even the tutorial encourages this bare-bones loop. I would have loved to see more depth here: perhaps more systems for processing goods, fulfilling contracts, or using a dedicated ‚Äúfarmer‚Äôs app‚Äù that could introduce more strategy and serve as the primary (or even sole) income source.

The cooking and stamina mechanics also feel somewhat unengaging. A more dynamic system‚Äîsimilar to what games like Valheim or Enshrouded utilize‚Äîcould make cooking and eating more purposeful. For example, we could have a natural stamina regeneration that is slow and capped, with food providing long-lasting boosts to regen rate and maximum stamina. A similar approach could work for health, adding another layer of decision-making.

The in-game economy would also benefit from a careful balance pass. While this is only a demo and many values are likely placeholder, it‚Äôs worth noting that cozy games don‚Äôt need to be ‚Äúeffortlessly easy.‚Äù Some level of challenge‚Äîor at least optional difficulty settings‚Äîcan go a long way toward keeping progression satisfying.

That said, the game does introduce some genuinely promising features:
-The DIY creation system, along with the ability to share and use community-made designs, is a standout addition.
-Relationship-building appears to have more depth and potential than what is typical for the genre.
-There‚Äôs an impressive variety of vehicles and mounts.
-Animal husbandry seems more nuanced, with animals contributing meaningfully to your farm‚Äîrabbits clearing weeds, for example.

Beyond mechanics, the game is visually stunning. The animations are charming, and small touches‚Äîlike your character changing into pajamas before going to bed‚Äîadd polish. Overall, the presentation gives the impression of a higher-budget production than many others in this genre.

The world design is beautiful, the atmosphere is relaxing. Character designs are cute. The game has potential. 

Gameplay, however, is clunky -- character movement doesn't feel fluid, and various mechanics just don't seem very intuitive or enjoyable. Animations don't flow well into other animations; jumping especially just feels bad. 

The vehicle system seems interesting, but the world is simply too laggy for it at this stage. Textures pop in and fps tanks when you ride a motorcycle. Not exactly fun. 

There's bugs and unfinished areas, including a few empty houses with walk-through walls. 

Character customization leaves a lot to be desired. It currently doesn't have many options. 

The previous points are things that could well be fixed in the full release. The game is slated for a Q1 2026 release, and there's time for polish. 

What concerns me the most, though, is the dialogue and the amount of machine translation used in the demo. 
The demo does have a disclaimer about the usage of machine-assisted translations, but they seem to have used a fair bit of it. 

Long bits of text (like character intro cards in the menu) are fatiguing to read due to the lack of localisation. It's not always fully clear when characters request things from the player outside of the mainline quests (and when they do, the requests often bug out). 

NPCs appear soulless because they don't speak like actual people. It remains to be seen whether that's due to the lack of localisation or if it's simply poor writing. Games like this are carried by their NPCs, and I hope the devs put actual work into the localisation and writing of them. Currently you can meet an NPC, talk to them once, gift them something in the same conversation, and they'll tell you that they appreciate you always giving them so many gifts.

The cozy games genre appeals to people who are incredibly kind and lenient with their games, and often devs take advantage of this by cutting corners. So far, the demo has left me anxious that this is another case of it.

The city is beautiful and really gives you the feeling of lived-in and loved community, the insides of buildings are gorgeous, there are plenty of free stuff you can pick up, the villagers and tourists even give you gifts even from Day 1. It is absolutely one of the more cozy and actually heartwarming games with welcoming characters ever.
But the sprawling nature surrounding it, which is where you would collect resources outside of your small farm, while beautiful even at low graphics, is unfortunately mostly empty. It was why you would eventually notice that your character moves weirdly slow.
They also have this minigame where you would stand and walk on the railings and jump from one to another. It should be very easy to do, but the weirdness of the character movement actually forces you to be very careful of it to do the minigame. It's not something you have to be careful about in normal gameplay, but the minigame really draws attention to it.

This game has a stamina bar as well, and it's surprisingly pretty generous right from the beginning, but we'll have to see if that remains in the full release. They also allow you to recover energy at 1 stamina (and more if you upgrade) per 1 in-game minute by sitting, which is really nice!
But, oh man, replenishing stamina through eating is kinda painful at the beginning (with the items that understandably replenish very little) because you either stand there for minutes, pushing mushrooms and berries down your throat, or you're in your inventory menu opening the sub-menu of the consumable to click 'eat' then you open the sub-menu again and click eat again and again and again...
Crafting on the workbench is also painful in the same sense. It's like Animal Crossing New Horizons where each item gets their own animation. I almost quit the demo when I had to craft the tools one by one and decided to push through it since not all production benches (furnace, charcoal kiln, cooking pot, etc) is as painful.

I'll proceed with the other features, like farming, fishing, logging, mining, catching bugs, 'hunting' animals, livestock raising, I swear. Let's go!
I won't comment on logging and mining much. It's fortunately standard. Farming is also mostly the same with some minor tweaks like crops growing within in-game hours and weeds growing in the farmlands.
Catching bugs is also technically the same, but clicking catch when the pop-up appears doesn't actually guarantee a catch, and you can catch bugs even without the pop-up appearing. I'd appreciate if the pop-up just doesn't appear at all or the bug catching be less about running after the bugs or making myself dizzy because the bug keeps circling around me so I have to keep rotating the camera.
Fishing is actually pretty fun! Unfortunately, it bugged out for me. The hook lands far away from me and made fishing harder.
'Hunting' animals is pretty interesting because they don't really allow you to 'hunt'. You're just incapacitating animals to capture and find new homes for them. But at least the animals, or at least the rabbits, are surprisingly useful because they would remove weeds from your farmlands, albeit for limited times per day.
As for livestock raising, it's still pretty standard with the feeding, affection levels, and juvenile and adult statuses. But it does have the interesting feature where each animal has their own positive stat, such as being 'strong' allows them to be ready for breeding again a day earlier than other animals.

Speaking of affection levels, the characters are quite nice and likable in many ways. Unfortunately, I cannot understand them sometimes as I am a scum who doesn't know Japanese.
I have to admit that I actually don't know much about them since I didn't want to read the dialogue. There's actually quite a lot of them, even for the tourists! They're all chatty.

As for other features that involve the NPCs, they have this Mentor System where you have to do quests for some NPCs (they're all romanceable characters, I think?) to get their approval of your expertise or something like that. Upgrading your level unlocks skills for farming, crafting, etc., which basically reduces stamina, increases chances of something happening, or giving your fun surprises for doing those activities.
It's actually... pretty nice! They're mostly fetch quests that are fortunately not super grindy. Kinda wish the currency for upgrading skills isn't used for anything else though.

Another complaint that I have is that the rain is just so heavy. It's the 'I need to pray for my safety' kind of heavy rain.

Once again, I want to reiterate that I love the game and I only wish for it to fix these little things because they do pile up and I don't want such minor things to ruin the full release of the game because it looks sooo promising!
Especially for me who's using a trashy and old gaming laptop, yet this game still runs and looks pretty well on the lowest graphic settings, and it doesn't make my laptop heat up like a boiling kettle.
Please become better. Please.
